_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan - Executive Summary

Facility:    MFA Agri Services - Glasgow
Location:    303 Industrial Drive, Glasgow, Mo.
Contact:     David Monnig
Phone:     660-338-5150


1. The Facility Policy

MFA Incorporated and the employees of the MFA Agri Services at Glasgow are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the Glasgow Fire Department, and other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.

2. Facility Information

The primary activity at the facility is the receiving, storage and distribution of anhydrous ammonia for direct application as a crop nutrient. The facility also stores grain.

The maximum quantity of anhydrous ammonia stored at any one time would be 1,990,800 pounds. The facility has (3) 30,000-gallon storage tanks, (1) 26,000-gallon storage tank and the largest tank onsite would be a railroad tank car containing approximately 160,000 pounds. There may be occasions where multiple railroad tank cars would be located at the facility. The maximum quantity handled would be the unloading of a railroad tank car holding approximately 160,000 pounds. The facility also has (65) 1,000-gallon nurse tanks, (1) 1,200-gallon nurse tanks and (2) 560-gallon applicator tanks for product distribution.  

3. The Accidental Release Prevention Program.

The facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1, 1981", published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc., the Missouri Anhydrous Ammonia Law and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and handling of Anhydrous Ammonia".

4. The Five-year Accident History

There have been no accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia in the past five years that: have caused any deaths, injuries, or significant property

damage at the facility; nor to our knowledge, have resulted in offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.

5. The Emergency Response Program.

The facility has;
    a. a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHA Standard, 29 CFR 1910.38;

    b. provided State and Local authorities with the emergency planning and community 
        right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA);

    c. a written emergency response program, in accordance with OSHA Standard, 29 CFR 
        1910.120, including pre-emergency planning and employee training.

6. Planned changes to improve safety.

Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility. Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. The facility has been evaluated for improvements to meet the requirements of the K61.1-1999 ANSI Code and improvements will be made in the near future.


    12/8/08
